text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Army was called out in southern Punjab city of Multan to maintain law and order after three people including a police official were injured in clashes between protestors and police.
- Shahbaz Sharif, chief minister of Pakistan's populace Punjab province, obtained vote of confidence from the provincial assembly securing a record 229 votes.
- Mehtab Ahmed Khan was sworn in as the new chief minister of North West Frontier Province.
- Mir Abdul Jabbar of the Jamhoori Watan Party, was unanimously electd as the Speaker of Balochistan provincial assembly.
- The Pakistan Muslim League and the Mohajir National Movement (MQM) formally signed their agreement that laid the basis of a new coalition government in Sindh.

- The U.S. State Department has confirmed it had sought no budgetary allocation from Congress for any military exchange and cooperation programme with Pakistan for the next financial year beginning in October.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will address the nation over radio and television on February 23 at 7.30 p.m. to outline his government's priorities.
- The government is holding a Businessmen Convention in the Federal Capital on February 26 to chalk out measures for reviving the economy.

- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has assured the president that his government will abide by commitments made by the caretakers with the International Monetary Fund to combat the critical economic situation of the country.
- ABN AMRO Bank and Deutche Morhan Grenfell (Singapore) Ltd have arranged a $ 115.5 million short-term financing facility for the Pakistan Telecommunication Company Limited.
- Automobile manufacturers and assemblers have joined hands with the vendor industry to counter the "pleadings" to allow free trade with India, sources in automobile sector said.
- To ease the chronic transport problem in the country, the government may allow the import of used cars and motorcycles.
- The prices of gold have significantly declined during the last three months all over the country.

- The sales of companies listed under the Karachi Stock Exchange's Auto and Allied Sector have grown by 48 percent since 1994 and average pay-out for the industry for 1996 comes to an admirable 20 percent.
